Berend de Boer <berend@...> writes:

> Hello All,
> 
> If you start doing URL rewriting you can make URLs that cannot exist
> in a file system. For example I can say that:
> 
>     /authors
> 
> returns a list of authors and
> 
>     /authors/peter
> 
> returns a single author.
> 
> But with URL rewriting it's just as easy to say that
> 
>   /authors/
> 
> returns the list of authors.

And you could say that

   /authors

returns the list of authors as well.


> My point is that /authors cannot exist in a file system if it has a
> subdirectory. 

Yes it can. It's the subdirectory itself. What that means is open to
interpretation. On un*x systems a directory is a special file
containing a list of the files and directorys contained within the
directory.


> (I think webservers send a moved/redirect if you ask for /authors or
> fetch the default page in that directory anyway??)

A lot of webservers do behave like that. But that behaviour is not
intrinsic to the way the web works. A webserver after all meerly maps
an arbritary URI based namespace to some behaviour (in this case
returning an index.html page or some such).

Apache just returns an index in this situation, the index behaviour
is often the commonly understood index.html trick. But it needn't be.
 

> But my question: for cases like this is it better to append a trailing
> slash if you want to get a list of things in a directory or does it
> not matter at all? So is:
> 
>     /authors
> 
> or
> 
>     /authors/
> 
> preferred?

The trailing slash does have an effect on HTML form posts for browser
contexts. If you're resource is:

   /authors/

you can have a form POST or GET to "." and it will go to the current
page. Having:

  /authors

as the resource and doing a POST or GET to "." will send the request
to:

  /


So there is a difference as far as common browsers are concerned. I'm
not sure it's spec compliant behaviour though. Just common.


Nic
